definitions: haggle or bargain persistently over the price or terms of a transaction
exchange goods or services through reciprocal bargaining rather than with money
examples: They dickered for hours over the antique furniture prices
The vendor refused to dicker about the wholesale delivery terms
Local farmers still dicker produce for handmade tools at markets
The tribes would dicker furs for metal implements and cloth

definitions: say words aloud for someone else to write down or for a recording device
give orders or commands with authority expecting them to be obeyed immediately
control or decisively influence how something happens or what form it takes
examples: She dictated the letter slowly to her assistant yesterday morning
The executive dictates all his correspondence into a voice recorder
The general dictated harsh terms to the defeated enemy forces
Parents shouldn't dictate every aspect of their children's lives
Market forces dictate the prices of most consumer goods today
Weather conditions will dictate whether the event proceeds as planned

definitions: pass time aimlessly or waste time on trivial activities without purpose
deceive or cheat someone especially in small financial matters or petty schemes
play with or manipulate something nervously or absent-mindedly with your fingers
examples: Stop diddling around and finish your homework before dinner tonight
He diddled away the entire afternoon watching television shows
The dishonest mechanic diddled customers by overcharging for simple repairs
She felt diddled when she discovered the tickets were counterfeit
The nervous student diddled with his pen throughout the examination
She constantly diddles with her phone even during important meetings

definitions: stop living and cease all biological functions permanently
stop working or functioning especially of machines or devices
gradually fade away disappear or come to an end
have an extremely strong desire or craving for something
examples: The elderly man died peacefully in his sleep last night
Many soldiers died defending their country during the war
My phone battery died during the important conference call yesterday
The car engine died suddenly on the highway this morning
The wind died down as the storm moved away eastward
Old traditions die hard in small rural communities everywhere
I'm dying to know what happened at the meeting
She's dying for a cup of coffee after the long night

definitions: deliberately limit or control food consumption especially to lose weight or for health
consume food and drink as part of one's regular nutritional intake
examples: She has been dieting strictly for three months before the wedding
Many people diet unsuccessfully because they choose unsustainable meal plans
Ancient Romans dieted mainly on bread olive oil and wine
Polar bears diet on seals and fish throughout the winter months

definitions: be dissimilar or unlike in nature quality or characteristics from something else
have a disagreement or hold contrasting opinions views or beliefs about something
examples: The twins differ greatly in their personalities and career interests
These two proposals differ only in minor technical implementation details
We differ on how to approach this complex marketing problem
Experts differ about the causes of the recent economic downturn

definitions: recognize or identify the differences between two or more things people or concepts
make something distinct or cause something to become different from others
find the derivative of a mathematical function using calculus
examples: Young children struggle to differentiate between fantasy and reality sometimes
The test helps differentiate genuine antiques from clever modern reproductions
Unique packaging differentiates our products from generic store brands effectively
Cells differentiate into specialized types during embryonic development stages
Students must differentiate this complex equation to find the maximum value
The professor asked us to differentiate the function with respect to x

definitions: spread over a wide area or between many people gradually and evenly
make something less concentrated intense or focused by spreading it out
examples: Light diffuses through the frosted glass creating soft ambient illumination
The pleasant aroma diffused throughout the entire house within minutes
The mediator tried to diffuse the tension during the heated negotiation
Adding water will diffuse the concentrated acid to safer levels

definitions: break up and move earth sand or other material using tools or hands
search through something thoroughly and systematically to find information or objects
understand appreciate or enjoy something especially in informal contexts
examples: The archaeologists carefully dig through ancient ruins seeking historical artifacts
The dog loves to dig holes in the backyard garden
Reporters dig into the politician's past looking for controversial stories
She had to dig through old files to find the contract
I really dig this new jazz album you recommended yesterday
He doesn't dig the modern art scene at all

definitions: break down food in the stomach and intestines into substances the body can absorb
understand and absorb complex information or ideas thoroughly through mental processing
examples: Some people cannot digest dairy products without experiencing uncomfortable symptoms
Snakes digest their prey very slowly over several days or weeks
Students need time to digest the complex mathematical concepts before testing
She couldn't digest all the technical information in one reading session

definitions: convert information images or signals from analog format into digital computer-readable format
examples: The library spent years digitizing its entire collection of historical manuscripts
Many companies digitize paper records to save storage space and improve accessibility

definitions: construct an embankment or wall to prevent flooding or control water flow
examples: Engineers diked the river to protect the town from seasonal flooding
The Dutch have diked much of their land to reclaim it from the sea

definitions: make a liquid thinner or less concentrated by adding water or another solvent
reduce the strength effectiveness or value of something by modification or addition
examples: Always dilute the cleaning solution according to the manufacturer's safety instructions
The bartender diluted the whiskey with water at the customer's request
Adding too many features will dilute the product's core value proposition
Immigration opponents claim new arrivals dilute national cultural identity significantly

definitions: make a light or illuminated object less bright or intense
become less bright intense or clear gradually over time
make something less distinct clear or easy to perceive
examples: Please dim the lights before the movie starts playing tonight
The restaurant dims its lights to create a romantic atmosphere
The stars dimmed as dawn approached from the eastern horizon
Her vision dimmed with age requiring stronger prescription glasses
Time had dimmed his memories of that traumatic childhood event
Don't let fear dim your hopes for a better future

definitions: determine and specify the measurements or proportions of something for design or construction
examples: The architect carefully dimensioned every room in the building blueprints
You need to dimension the parts accurately before starting the manufacturing process

definitions: make or become smaller weaker or less in size amount or intensity
make something seem less important valuable or impressive than it actually is
examples: The pain gradually diminished after taking the prescribed medication yesterday
Rising costs diminish the purchasing power of fixed income pensioners
His rude comments diminished her achievements in front of the board
Don't diminish your own accomplishments by comparing yourself to others

definitions: produce or form small hollows or indentations in a surface especially when smiling
examples: Her cheeks dimpled charmingly whenever she smiled at the camera
The golf ball dimpled the soft green when it landed hard

definitions: make a loud unpleasant and prolonged noise that continues without stopping
examples: The construction machinery dinned constantly throughout the entire working day
Traffic dinned in his ears as he tried to sleep

definitions: eat dinner especially in a formal setting or at a restaurant
V + on + O
examples: They dine at exclusive restaurants every Friday evening together
The ambassador dined with foreign dignitaries at the state banquet

definitions: make a short ringing sound like that of a bell or metal object
cause a dent or minor damage to a surface especially metal
examples: The elevator dings when it reaches each floor of the building
The timer dinged indicating the cookies were ready to remove
Someone dinged my car door in the parking lot yesterday
Be careful not to ding the furniture while moving it

definitions: put something briefly into liquid and then remove it quickly
go down or decline to a lower level position or amount
scoop up liquid or soft substance with a ladle or container
examples: She dipped the brush in paint before applying it to canvas
Dip the vegetables in ranch dressing for a tasty snack
The sun dipped below the horizon painting the sky orange
Stock prices dipped sharply following the earnings announcement yesterday
The chef dipped soup from the pot into individual serving bowls
She dipped water from the well using an old wooden bucket

definitions: aim guide or point something or someone toward a particular destination or target
control and manage the operations of an organization project or performance
give authoritative instructions or orders to someone about what they should do
examples: She directed the lost tourists to the nearest subway station
The surgeon directed the laser beam precisely at the tumor
Spielberg directed many blockbuster movies throughout his long successful career
She directs a team of fifty software engineers at the company
The judge directed the jury to disregard that inappropriate testimony
The manager directed employees to work overtime this weekend

definitions: make something unclean soiled or contaminated with dirt dust or stains
examples: The children dirtied their clothes playing in the muddy garden
Don't dirty the clean floor with your muddy boots please

definitions: make a device system or function unable to work or operate properly
cause someone to have a physical or mental condition that limits their abilities
examples: The virus disabled the computer's security system within minutes yesterday
You can disable notifications in the application settings menu
The accident disabled him permanently requiring use of a wheelchair
The disease can disable victims by attacking their nervous system

definitions: put someone or something in an unfavorable position relative to others
examples: The new regulations disadvantage small businesses competing against large corporations
Poor internet access disadvantages rural students in online learning environments

definitions: have or express a different opinion from someone else about something
be inconsistent incompatible or fail to correspond with something else
examples: The committee members disagree about the best approach to the problem
I respectfully disagree with your interpretation of the data
The witness accounts disagree on several important details of the incident
These measurements disagree with our theoretical predictions significantly

definitions: refuse to allow permit or accept something officially or formally
examples: The referee disallowed the goal due to an offside violation
The court disallowed the evidence because it was obtained illegally

definitions: cease to be visible or stop being in sight suddenly or gradually
cease to exist or be lost completely without trace or explanation
examples: The magician made the rabbit disappear from the hat instantly
The ship disappeared into the fog never to return
Many species disappear every year due to habitat destruction worldwide
The ancient civilization disappeared mysteriously leaving only ruins behind

definitions: fail to fulfill the hopes expectations or wishes of someone causing sadness
examples: The movie disappointed fans who expected something more original and exciting
I hate to disappoint you but the concert has been cancelled

definitions: have or express an unfavorable opinion about something or someone
officially refuse to agree to or accept something formally
examples: Her parents strongly disapprove of her decision to drop out
Many voters disapprove of the government's handling of the crisis
The board disapproved the proposed merger citing antitrust concerns yesterday
The planning committee disapproved the construction permit application

definitions: take weapons away from someone or remove military equipment from a place
make someone less hostile angry or suspicious through charm or friendliness
make a bomb or explosive device safe by removing or deactivating it
examples: The police disarmed the suspect without anyone getting hurt yesterday
The treaty required both nations to disarm their nuclear arsenals
Her sincere apology disarmed his anger about the missed deadline completely
His warm smile disarmed even the most skeptical audience members
The bomb squad carefully disarmed the explosive device found downtown
Experts disarmed the landmines left from the previous conflict

definitions: bring into a state of disorganization untidiness or confusion
examples: The sudden storm disarrayed all the outdoor wedding decorations completely
Budget cuts have disarrayed the entire educational system this year

definitions: disconnect or separate oneself from a person group or organization
examples: The company disassociated itself from the controversial spokesperson immediately
She decided to disassociate from her former business partners permanently

definitions: deny any responsibility for knowledge of or support for something or someone
examples: The politician disavowed his earlier controversial statements about immigration policy
The organization disavowed the violent actions of its radical members

definitions: cause an organized group to stop existing or operating as a unit
examples: The committee disbanded after completing its investigation into the scandal
The government disbanded the special military unit due to budget constraints

definitions: get rid of something as no longer useful or desirable
reject or abandon something from a set of options or possibilities
examples: Please discard any expired medications in the proper disposal container
She discarded the broken dishes rather than trying to repair them
The editor discarded several chapters from the final manuscript version
Players must discard two cards before drawing new ones

definitions: perceive recognize or distinguish something with difficulty that is not immediately obvious
examples: She could barely discern his face in the darkness ahead
The expert discerned subtle differences between the two paintings immediately

definitions: officially release someone from a duty job hospital or military service
emit release or allow to flow out from a container or source
fulfill or carry out a duty responsibility or debt completely
examples: The hospital discharged the patient after a successful recovery period
The army discharged him with honors after twenty years service
The factory illegally discharged toxic waste into the nearby river
The wound continued to discharge fluid for several days afterward
She discharged all her duties as executor of the estate efficiently
The court ruled he had discharged his debt through bankruptcy

definitions: punish someone especially a child to correct behavior or maintain order
train oneself or others to follow rules or a code of behavior
examples: The school disciplined students who violated the dress code policy
Parents must discipline their children consistently but fairly
Athletes discipline themselves through rigorous daily training routines
The military disciplines recruits to follow orders without hesitation

definitions: make secret or new information known publicly or to specific people
examples: The company must disclose financial information to its shareholders annually
She finally disclosed the truth about her past to her family

definitions: change to a different color especially in an unattractive or undesirable way
examples: Sunlight discolored the curtains from blue to a faded gray
The metal discolored after being exposed to harsh chemicals

definitions: break or interrupt the connection between two things or systems
become emotionally or mentally detached from reality or other people
examples: The technician disconnected the cable before starting the repair work
Please disconnect all devices from the power source during storms
He felt completely disconnected from his colleagues after working remotely
Teenagers often disconnect from family during adolescent years

definitions: cease doing providing making or using something permanently or temporarily
examples: The manufacturer discontinued the product due to poor sales performance
The doctor recommended discontinuing the medication after two weeks

definitions: reduce the usual price of something by a specific amount or percentage
regard something as unworthy of consideration or less significant than claimed
examples: The store discounted all winter clothing by fifty percent yesterday
Airlines often discount tickets for flights departing midweek
Don't discount her advice just because she's young and inexperienced
Scientists shouldn't discount theories without proper experimental testing

definitions: cause someone to lose confidence enthusiasm or hope about doing something
try to prevent something from happening by showing disapproval or creating difficulties
examples: The initial failures discouraged her from pursuing her artistic dreams
Don't let temporary setbacks discourage you from reaching your goals
High prices discourage people from buying organic produce regularly
The new regulations discourage foreign investment in local markets

definitions: speak or write authoritatively and at length about a particular topic
examples: The professor discoursed brilliantly on medieval European history for hours
She loves to discourse about philosophy with her intellectual friends

definitions: find something or someone unexpectedly or during a search for the first time
become aware of a fact or situation that was previously unknown
examples: Columbus discovered America in 1492 while searching for India
Scientists discovered a new species of frog in the Amazon
She discovered her passport was missing at the airport checkpoint
He discovered that his wife had been lying about her past

definitions: harm the good reputation or respectability of someone or something
cause an idea or theory to be doubted or no longer accepted
examples: The scandal completely discredited the politician's career and future ambitions
False accusations were used to discredit the whistleblower's testimony
New evidence discredited the long-held theory about climate patterns
The study's flawed methodology discredited its controversial conclusions entirely

definitions: treat a person or group differently and unfairly based on prejudice
recognize a distinction between things or people based on specific criteria
examples: The company was sued for discriminating against older job applicants
It's illegal to discriminate based on race gender or religion
Wine experts can discriminate between subtle flavors in different vintages
Young children cannot discriminate between fantasy and reality easily

definitions: talk or write about a topic in detail considering different ideas and opinions
examples: The board will discuss the merger proposal at tomorrow's meeting
Students discussed the novel's themes in their literature class yesterday
